metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.5 runoff observation system of Ban bridge on the Heihe River, 2013)
metadata.description:
The No. 5 hydrological section is located at Ban Bridge (100.276° E, 39.259° N, 1398 m) in the midstream of the Heihe River Basin, Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The dataset contains observations recorded by the No.5 hydrological section from 19 June, 2012, to 10 August, 2012. The width of this section is 270 meters. The water level was measured using an HOBO pressure range and the discharge was measured using cross-section reconnaissance by the StreamPro ADCP. The dataset includes the following parameters: water level (recorded every 30 minutes) and discharge. The missing and incorrect (outside the normal range) data were replaced with -6999.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), He et al. (2016) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

background: The impact of global warming on precipitation, specifically in the western part of China (approximately divided by 103°E), has shown a general increasing trend in annual precipitation over the past 30 years. As a key area for hydrological and climate research, the Tibetan Plateau exhibits extreme complexity in the spatial and temporal distribution of precipitation due to its varied topography and terrain. Additionally, the representativeness of precipitation data has been a weak link in related research due to the distribution of observation points and the limitations of manual observations. On the other hand, in the cold climate of the Tibetan Plateau, the observational errors caused by solid precipitation have a particularly strong impact on the measurement of precipitation amounts. Therefore, precipitation observation in the Tibetan Plateau is a pressing issue that needs to be addressed.
research objective: Therefore, in response to this situation, this article conducts a comparative analysis and correction of precipitation observations in the central Tanggula Mountains region of the Tibetan Plateau.
challenges: Due to the distribution of precipitation observation points and the limitations of manual observations, the representativeness of precipitation data has always been a weak link in related research. In the cold climate of the Tibetan Plateau, the observational errors caused by solid precipitation have a particularly strong impact on the measurement of precipitation amounts.
methods: From May to October 2005, continuous artificial meteorological observations were conducted in the middle reaches of the Dongkema River basin in the Tanggula Mountains on the Tibetan Plateau. During the observation period, based on the correlation between different types of precipitation and temperature, a critical temperature of 2.7°C was used to classify precipitation types. Using the correction formulas for the T-200B automatic rain and snow gauge and ordinary rain gauge, precipitation was corrected and compared on a daily scale. Based on the classification of precipitation types, the T-200B automatic rain gauge was corrected using formula (3) and measured wind speed, resulting in precipitation amounts that were closer to the actual values.
findings: The correction results show that the total accumulated precipitation of the T-200B automatic rain and snow gauge increased to 87% of DFIR, significantly higher than the 36% before correction, indicating a clear improvement. The corrected precipitation values obtained by classifying precipitation types based on temperature increased by approximately 16.8% compared to the original gauge observations, while the precipitation values calculated based on actual observed precipitation types increased by 17.7% compared to the original observations. The use of temperature indicators to classify precipitation types for correcting the precipitation observations of the T-200B automatic rain and snow gauge can fully adapt to the harsh natural environment of the plateau and enable long-term automatic precipitation monitoring. Compared to the precipitation observed in 1993, the corrected annual precipitation of 662.1 mm at the same location is much greater than the total annual precipitation of 472 mm recorded at that time.

Definition.Question: What is a multiscale dataset, and why is it important in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A multiscale dataset is a collection of data obtained from various hierarchically nested scales, capturing diverse eco-hydrological processes. It is important in eco-hydrological research because it provides comprehensive, multi-disciplinary data that addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations, facilitating a better understanding of complex interactions in heterogeneous landscapes.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with hydrometeorological data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with hydrometeorological data collection in arid and semiarid regions include ecological environment degradation, drying up of water sources, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, which complicate the acquisition and accuracy of long-term observational data.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using automated instruments like the HOBO pressure water level meter in hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: The use of automated instruments like the HOBO pressure water level meter in hydrological data collection is significant because they provide consistent, high-frequency observations of water levels, which are crucial for developing water level-flow curves and understanding runoff changes over time, especially in dynamic environments like riverbeds with unstable cross-sections.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the Heihe Watershed experiment compare to those used in the artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in terms of capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The Heihe Watershed experiment utilizes a hierarchically nested scale system with instruments like eddy covariance towers and remote sensing tools to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, the datasets from oasis–desert systems focus on long-term data collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, supplemented with hydrometeorological and vegetation data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of data collection in arid regions differ from those in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, particularly concerning precipitation observations?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection in arid regions faces challenges such as ecological environment degradation and the need for long-term observations to maintain oasis-desert balance. In the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, challenges include the extreme complexity of precipitation spatial distribution due to topography and the significant impact of solid precipitation on observation accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of various remote sensing technologies enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, as part of a hierarchically nested observation system, allows researchers to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. This integration provides comprehensive data that supports the investigation of interactions in oasis-desert systems, thereby facilitating better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, and how do observational datasets contribute to addressing these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers, land desertification, and dust storms. Observational datasets, which include long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes as well as hydrometeorological data, offer critical insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. This quantitative understanding is vital for achieving sustainable oasis development and supporting ecological security.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are essential for improving the accuracy of precipitation observation in complex high-altitude regions?
Interpretation.Answer: In high-altitude regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, challenges such as the distribution of observation points and solid precipitation measurement errors necessitate methodological improvements. By using temperature as a criterion to classify precipitation types and applying corrections to automated precipitation gauges, researchers can achieve more accurate precipitation measurements. This approach adapts to the harsh natural environment and supports long-term automated observation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes within heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a significant challenge in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. The HiWATER experiment addresses this challenge by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the significant observational errors in precipitation data collection in the Tibetan Plateau, and how can these errors be addressed?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Observational errors in precipitation data collection in the Tibetan Plateau are primarily due to the region's complex terrain and the limitations in the distribution of observation points. Additionally, solid precipitation leads to significant errors in measurement. These issues can be addressed by using temperature as a criterion for classifying precipitation types and employing correction formulas for existing instruments, such as the T-200B automatic rain gauge, to improve the accuracy of observed precipitation data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of implementing multiscale observation networks on understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing multiscale observation networks can significantly enhance the understanding of oasis-desert interactions by capturing eco-hydrological processes at various scales. This approach can provide detailed insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of creating a multiscale dataset in the context of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface, which is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. The dataset aims to capture these processes through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, facilitating a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological security and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to have a network of hydrometeorological and flux observation stations in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is crucial to maintain a network of observation stations in these regions to quantitatively understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This understanding is essential for recognizing the interactions between oasis and desert systems, thus supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development. Such a network provides long-term data necessary to achieve sustainable oasis development goals and carbon neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind implementing intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations in the HiWATER experiment?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data to address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations. By implementing IOPs and continuous observations, the HiWATER experiment aims to gain insights into the eco-hydrological processes and interactions within the oasis-desert system, thereby advancing the field's understanding and facilitating better management and development strategies in arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures involved in using HOBO pressure water level sensors for river stage measurements, and how is the data frequency managed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: HOBO pressure water level sensors are used to measure river stage at a frequency of 30 minutes. The data collected includes river water levels and flow velocities, which are then used to derive a stage-discharge curve. Missing data are indicated by the string -6999. The data is collected continuously over specified periods to monitor changes in runoff.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale eco-hydrological processes captured and integrated using hierarchically nested observation systems, and what types of instruments are typically involved?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale eco-hydrological processes are captured using a hierarchically nested observation system that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network. The instruments are arranged to capture data across different scales, including airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, to investigate oasis-desert interactions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in processing and quality controlling long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux datasets collected from oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing and quality control of long-term datasets involve several steps, including data collection, processing, and archiving. Data is collected from instruments like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, with hydrometeorological parameters also recorded. The datasets include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as vegetation and soil parameters, all of which undergo quality control to ensure accuracy before being shared with data centers.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of hierarchically nested instrumentation, including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, allows for the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes.

Enablement.Question: How do observational networks enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Observational networks, consisting of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, enable a quantitative understanding of the oasis-desert interactions, which is critical for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why might the availability of multiscale observations be challenging in eco-hydrological research, and how can data collection methods be improved to address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in the field of eco-hydrological research is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. To address these challenges, HiWATER implemented an observation system with hierarchically nested scales and conducted intensive observation periods, using a combination of eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. Improving data collection could involve expanding the network of these instruments and ensuring continuous, long-term observations to capture the complex interactions in such ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in obtaining reliable precipitation data in regions like the Tibetan Plateau, and how can data collection methods be adapted to overcome these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: In regions like the Tibetan Plateau, the distribution of observation points and limitations in manual observations make it challenging to obtain representative precipitation data. The use of automatic rain gauges, like the T-200B, can improve data accuracy by adjusting for solid precipitation errors. Employing temperature-based criteria to classify precipitation types and correcting measurements accordingly can also enhance the reliability of long-term automated observations in such harsh environments.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems, and what datasets or data collection methods could support this objective?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial for sustainable development and ecological stability. Datasets that capture long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological and vegetation data, are vital. Data collection methods should include a combination of eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations, and ground-based observations to provide comprehensive insights into these complex interactions and support ecological security and socioeconomic development.

Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for capturing eco-hydrological processes involve the use of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales. A sparse network was established to investigate oasis-desert interactions, with a superstation constructed within the oasis, and additional stations including EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in surrounding landscapes like sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland.

Request/Directive.Question: Please conduct a search for datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems and summarize the types of data available.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include long-term observational data from both natural and artificial systems. The data consist of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, hydrometeorological data (such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles), air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Vegetation and soil parameters are also included. These datasets are freely available at platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
